title: John Batchelor Electioneering Promises for Small Business Taxes
description:
Electioneering Promises for Small Business Taxes. Gene Marks, WashingtonPost.com.

But even assuming that the Tax Foundationâ€™s numbers come to pass, thereâ€™s still too much information missing to determine who has the best tax plan. Yes, weâ€™ve heard about the revenues. But what about the expenses? Iâ€™ve never read a profit and loss statement with only revenues included. So whereâ€™s my complete P&L?

When anyone in business proposes a change to their companyâ€™s business - a big investment, a new product line, a change in model â€“ there are projections. We donâ€™t just budget the good stuff (the hoped-for revenues) but we also include the not-so-good stuff (the costs). Politicians are experts at highlighting the â€œgoodâ€ and downplaying the â€œbad.â€

Tax decreases are good. But a $19 trillion national debt and projected trillion dollar deficits over the next decade are bad. Saying that youâ€™re going to â€œclean up governmentâ€ and â€œget rid of wasteâ€ isnâ€™t good enough. Business people need more information than that. We like to know both sides of the story: the revenue coming in and the costs going out. Just because Clintonâ€™s and Sandersâ€™ plans will increase revenues to the government over the next 10 years, what exactly will they be spending? And if Cruzâ€™s and Trumpâ€™s plans are going to create a hole in Federal revenue inlays, where will the expenses be correspondingly reduced?
